Package com.robix.nexway

Provides access to Robix Usbor Servo Controllers (Start Here).

See:
          Description

Interface Summary
Cam Interface for cameras.
Digout Interface for digital outputs.
NexusConnection This interface provides access to a local or remote Robix Nexus application.
Pod Interface for pods (aka robots, organs, ...).
Sensor Interface for sensors.
Servo Interface for servos.
Usbor Interface for Usbor devices.
 

Class Summary
Cognit This class contains information about an observed/recognized blob in a Cam image.
Cognit.Fit This class contains 'fit' (object-matching) information.
CognitionParams These parameters control the behavior of the recognition algorithms in the Robix Shape-Vision software.
ConnectError Asynchronous Nexus connection errors.
ConnectState Asynchronous Nexus connection states.
Nexway A Nexway object is the main entry point for Robix Usbor control.
PodAction Pod actions.
PodScript Simple container which represents a Pod script.
PodShoppingList This class exists in order to efficiently select specific Pod data points and then fetch only relevant data as it changes.
ScriptingInfo Helper class which contains a snapshot of a Pod's scripting information.
ServoProperty Servo properties.
 

Package com.robix.nexway Description

Provides access to Robix Usbor Servo Controllers (Start Here).

Usbor JAR

All of the Robix classes required by this API are contained in the JAR file "rbxUsbor.jar" which is in the /lib directory of the Usbor software.
Default location:
Windows: C:\Program Files\Robix\Usbor\lib\rbxUsbor.jar
Mac OSX: /Applications/Robix/Usbor/lib/rbxUsbor.jar
Linux: /opt/Robix/Usbor/lib/rbxUsbor.jar

In order to use this API in your programs, you should include rbxUsbor.jar in your classpath when compiling and running your Java app.
e.g.
javac -classpath <usbor_home>/lib/rbxUsbor.jar MyApp.java
java -classpath <usbor_home>/lib/rbxUsbor.jar MyApp

Nexway-Nexus Relationship

Controlling Usbor Pods (aka Robots, Organs, ...) requires two major components, a Nexus and a Nexway.

The Nexus is a stand-alone application which communicates directly with Usbor devices through USB. The Nexus then provides access to the Usbors via TCP/IP connections.

A Nexway is, as the name implies, a "gateway to the Nexus". A Nexway establishes a TCP/IP connection to the Nexus in order to control Pods.

In many respects, a Nexway-Nexus connection can be viewed as a client-server relationship. A single Nexus (server) can accept connections from many Nexways (clients). A single Nexway may connect to several Nexi (plural of Nexus) simultaneously. A single computer can host only one Nexus but many Nexways.

Nexway API

The Nexway class is the entry point to this API and the root of an object hierarchy as described below. 
Nexway
|
'---NexusConnection*
    |
    |---Usbor*
    |   |
    |   '---Pod*
    |       |
    |       '---Servo*
    |       '---Digout*
    |       '---Sensor*
    |
    '---Cam*

* zero or more
General steps necessary to control pods:
  • Make sure the Nexus application is running on local (or remote) computer.
  • Create a Nexway.
  • Create a NexusConnection object.
  • Connect to the local (or remote) Nexus application.
  • "Discover" Usbors that are provided by the Nexus.
  • "Discover" Pods that are provided by the Usbor.
  • Once you have a reference to a Pod, you can run scripts, read sensors, monitor servo positions, etc.

These steps are illustrated in the example programs which accompany the Usbor software.

It is important to understand that Pod commands (assignMainScript(), runMainMacro(), stopScript(), etc.) are executed asynchronously and may even be queued if the Pod is busy.

For example, when you call runQuickScript(), the method does not wait for the script to execute--the method returns immediately, and the script will run "later". When is "later"? It depends. If you are connected to a Nexus on your local computer, a message may travel so quickly that it appears instantaneous. On the other hand, if you are connected to a Nexus that is on the other side of the globe, it may be a while before your script reaches its destination. It is not the intent of this API (nor the Usbor software system) to provide time-critical Pod control. Rather, we provide a more "relaxed" approach to control and sensory observation.

Example Programs

Please see the example programs for an introduction to programming with this API. Examples are available for Java, C/C++, and Visual Basic.
Default examples directory:
Windows: C:\Program Files\Robix\Usbor\examples
Mac OSX: /Applications/Robix/Usbor/examples
Linux: /opt/Robix/Usbor/examples

Thread Safety

All classes in this package are thread-safe, unless otherwise noted.

Version:
1.1.0 -- 2005-03-21
